title: How to Recover from an Abortion

steps.headline: Rest and relax on the day of your procedure.
steps.description: You’ll likely go home after your procedure to continue your recovery at home. Take it easy for the rest of the day. Sit or lie down as much as possible, and relax so that your body can recover. Follow all of your doctor’s advice so that you can feel better. If you have any questions, call your doctor’s office to ask.

steps.headline: Return to your normal activities the day after your procedure.
steps.description: You should be able to resume your normal life the day after you get your abortion. Just don’t push yourself to do too much too fast. Take it easy and listen to your body. If your doctor recommends you rest longer, follow their advice.

steps.headline: Stop any activity that triggers your pain.
steps.description: You'll likely have cramps and pain for a week or 2 after your abortion as your body adjusts back to its pre-pregnancy state. Some activities may make your pain worse. If this happens, stop the activity and rest until you feel better. For instance, you might start to feel pain while carrying your groceries. If this happens, stop and ask someone to help you.

steps.headline: Avoid strenuous activity for the first week after your abortion.
steps.description: You might feel better right after your procedure, especially if you had your abortion early in your pregnancy. However, it’s still important that you rest your body as you recover. Don’t engage in exercise or any activity that strains your body for at least a week. This gives you time to heal and helps prevent discomfort. You may be able to do low-impact exercises or yoga. However, check with your doctor first.

steps.headline: Avoid activities that can cause an infection for at least a week.
steps.description:
After your abortion, your cervix will take time to close. This means you’re at a greater risk for infection in your cervix or fallopian tubes in the week following your abortion. To protect yourself, avoid products and activities that might lead to an infection. Here are some precautions you should take for at least 1 week:
Don’t have sex. Use pads instead of tampons. Avoid fragrances, bubble baths, bath salts, and bath bombs. Don’t go swimming. Skip douching.

steps.headline: Take your prescribed antibiotic to help prevent an infection.
steps.description: Your doctor might prescribe an antibiotic to help you recover without developing an infection. Take your medication exactly as directed so that you don’t risk an infection. Don’t stop taking your medication even if you start to feel better. It’s possible that you could develop an infection.

steps.headline: Care for the normal side effects of an abortion.
steps.description:
Your side effects might cause you discomfort, but you’ll start to feel better in a few weeks. Expect your side effects to peak after 3-5 days. Then, they’ll start to improve. Here’s what to watch for:

Bleeding or spotting that lasts for 2-6 weeks (though you might not bleed at all)
Bleeding that starts 3-5 days after your abortion
Discharge that’s brown or black
Cramping that’s slightly more painful than a period
Tender, swollen breasts
Fatigue

steps.headline: Get medical treatment if you experience severe side effects.
steps.description:
While you likely don’t need to worry, you might develop severe side effects if there’s a complication. If there is a complication, you’ll likely experience the effects within 1 week of the procedure. If this happens, you need quick treatment so you can get better. Call your doctor or visit an emergency room if you have the following symptoms:
Fever over 101 °F (38 °C)
Chills
Heavy bleeding, such as soaking through 2 or more pads in an hour
A blood clot the size of a lemon
Severe pain or cramping that medication doesn’t relieve
Nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea that lasts longer than 24 hours
Fainting or dizziness
Foul smelling vaginal discharge
Pregnancy symptoms 2 weeks after your abortion
Depression

steps.headline: Attend a follow-up appointment 3-4 weeks after your procedure.
steps.description: Visit your doctor to get a check-up to make sure you’re recovering properly. Usually, this will be a routine visit. If you have any questions about your recovery, ask them during your appointment. If you aren’t currently taking birth control, it’s a good idea to discuss your options during your follow-up appointment.

steps.headline: Take ibuprofen every 6-8 hours if your doctor approves it.
steps.description: You may experience some mild cramps in your lower abdomen for 2-4 days after you have an abortion. Over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) will treat your pain and cramps. Check with your doctor to make sure it’s safe for you to take NSAIDs. Then, take your medication every 6-8 hours to ease your pain. Ibuprofen isn’t right for everyone. If you can’t use it, try acetaminophen (Tylenol) to treat your pain.

steps.headline: Apply a heating bad or warm compress to your pelvis for 15-30 minutes.
steps.description: Heat will relieve your pain and cramps. Place a heating pad or compress over your lower pelvis for 15-30 minutes at a time. This will help ease your discomfort and may reduce cramping. You can use your heating pad or compress as often as you need it to help with your pain.

steps.headline: Give yourself a 10-minute uterine massage to ease your cramps.
steps.description: Use your fingers to gently rub your lower abdomen. Apply a massage oil or lotion over your pelvic area to make it easier for your fingers to glide over your skin. Make circular motions to soothe your muscles and relieve your cramps. You can massage your lower abdomen as often as necessary.

steps.headline: Sip on warm liquids like tea or cocoa to soothe your pain.
steps.description: Warm liquids will relax your body, which may help relieve your pain. Make your favorite tea or a mug of cocoa or simply drink hot water. Sip your beverage slowly to help you relax. You might also enjoy hot soups, such as chicken noodle soup. The hot broth can be soothing.

steps.headline: Stay away from people who won’t understand.
steps.description: While many people will be there to support you, some people may judge your decision or say hurtful things. These people won’t help your recovery, so don’t let them around you. Instead, spend time with people who are there to help you. If you think someone might have a bad reaction, don’t tell them about your abortion. You don’t need their opinion about your healthcare needs.

steps.headline: Give yourself permission to grieve if you're upset.
steps.description: While having an abortion may have been your best or only option, you might still feel a sense of sadness or loss. It’s normal to feel this way, and it doesn’t mean you made the wrong decision. Let yourself feel whatever comes naturally, and take your time during your recovery. Be aware: Some circumstances will put you at greater risk of having a difficult emotional recovery after an abortion. These include a history of previous emotional problems (such as depression or anxiety disorders), severe medical complications, coercion or lack of support from family members or your partner, or having to terminate a wanted pregnancy. It might be especially painful for you if you had to have an abortion because your pregnancy wasn’t viable. It’s normal to feel a lot of pain right now. Take as long as you need to feel better.

steps.headline: Talk to someone you trust about the feelings you’re having.
steps.description:
Reach out to your partner, a friend, or a family member you can trust. Tell them how you feel and ask them to be there to support you during your recovery. This can help you process your feelings faster. You might say, “I know this was the best decision, but I still feel sad. Can I call you when I need to talk?”
Don’t confide in someone who might judge you. Right now you need love and support.Tip: It’s normal to experience a range of emotions after an abortion. You might feel elated or relieved, but you could also feel sad or guilty. It’s okay to feel what comes naturally to you.

steps.headline: Do fun activities to help you feel better.
steps.description: It might feel wrong to enjoy yourself right now, but it’s okay to do things that make you feel good. Take time for yourself every day to do something you enjoy. Here are some ways you might start to feel better. Express yourself through art. Watch funny movies. Listen to uplifting music. Color in an adult coloring book. Spend time with your friends.

steps.headline: Talk to your doctor if your emotional pain troubles you.
steps.description: It’s normal for your hormones to fluctuate a lot after you have an abortion. You might even develop the symptoms of postpartum depression. If you’re worried that you’re depressed, talk to your doctor about how you feel. They may offer you treatment options. You aren’t to blame for feeling depressed. This is a medical issue, so visit your doctor.

steps.headline: Visit a therapist if you need help dealing with your grief.
steps.description: You might need extra support during your recovery, and that’s okay. Work with a therapist to help you process your emotions and continue your recovery. Ask your doctor for a referral or look up a therapist online. Your counseling sessions may be covered by your insurance, so check your benefits.

tyn: heating pad and/or hot water bottle
supportive partner, friends, family, mentors, and/or counselors
text:
Taking Care of Yourself Rest and relax on the day of your procedure. You’ll likely go home after your procedure to continue your recovery at home. Take it easy for the rest of the day. Sit or lie down as much as possible, and relax so that your body can recover. Follow all of your doctor’s advice so that you can feel better. If you have any questions, call your doctor’s office to ask. Return to your normal activities the day after your procedure. You should be able to resume your normal life the day after you get your abortion. Just don’t push yourself to do too much too fast. Take it easy and listen to your body. If your doctor recommends you rest longer, follow their advice. Stop any activity that triggers your pain. You'll likely have cramps and pain for a week or 2 after your abortion as your body adjusts back to its pre-pregnancy state. Some activities may make your pain worse. If this happens, stop the activity and rest until you feel better. For instance, you might start to feel pain while carrying your groceries. If this happens, stop and ask someone to help you. Avoid strenuous activity for the first week after your abortion. You might feel better right after your procedure, especially if you had your abortion early in your pregnancy. However, it’s still important that you rest your body as you recover. Don’t engage in exercise or any activity that strains your body for at least a week. This gives you time to heal and helps prevent discomfort. You may be able to do low-impact exercises or yoga. However, check with your doctor first. Avoid activities that can cause an infection for at least a week. After your abortion, your cervix will take time to close. This means you’re at a greater risk for infection in your cervix or fallopian tubes in the week following your abortion. To protect yourself, avoid products and activities that might lead to an infection. Here are some precautions you should take for at least 1 week:
Don’t have sex. Use pads instead of tampons. Avoid fragrances, bubble baths, bath salts, and bath bombs. Don’t go swimming. Skip douching. Take your prescribed antibiotic to help prevent an infection. Your doctor might prescribe an antibiotic to help you recover without developing an infection. Take your medication exactly as directed so that you don’t risk an infection. Don’t stop taking your medication even if you start to feel better. It’s possible that you could develop an infection. Care for the normal side effects of an abortion. Your side effects might cause you discomfort, but you’ll start to feel better in a few weeks. Expect your side effects to peak after 3-5 days. Then, they’ll start to improve. Here’s what to watch for:

Bleeding or spotting that lasts for 2-6 weeks (though you might not bleed at all)
Bleeding that starts 3-5 days after your abortion
Discharge that’s brown or black
Cramping that’s slightly more painful than a period
Tender, swollen breasts
Fatigue Get medical treatment if you experience severe side effects. While you likely don’t need to worry, you might develop severe side effects if there’s a complication. If there is a complication, you’ll likely experience the effects within 1 week of the procedure. If this happens, you need quick treatment so you can get better. Call your doctor or visit an emergency room if you have the following symptoms:
Fever over 101 °F (38 °C)
Chills
Heavy bleeding, such as soaking through 2 or more pads in an hour
A blood clot the size of a lemon
Severe pain or cramping that medication doesn’t relieve
Nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea that lasts longer than 24 hours
Fainting or dizziness
Foul smelling vaginal discharge
Pregnancy symptoms 2 weeks after your abortion

If you have any questions about your recovery, ask them during your appointment. If you aren’t currently taking birth control, it’s a good idea to discuss your options during your follow-up appointment. Relieving Your Pain Take ibuprofen every 6-8 hours if your doctor approves it. You may experience some mild cramps in your lower abdomen for 2-4 days after you have an abortion. Over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) will treat your pain and cramps. Check with your doctor to make sure it’s safe for you to take NSAIDs. Then, take your medication every 6-8 hours to ease your pain. Ibuprofen isn’t right for everyone. If you can’t use it, try acetaminophen (Tylenol) to treat your pain. Apply a heating bad or warm compress to your pelvis for 15-30 minutes. Heat will relieve your pain and cramps. Place a heating pad or compress over your lower pelvis for 15-30 minutes at a time. This will help ease your discomfort and may reduce cramping. You can use your heating pad or compress as often as you need it to help with your pain. Give yourself a 10-minute uterine massage to ease your cramps. Use your fingers to gently rub your lower abdomen. Apply a massage oil or lotion over your pelvic area to make it easier for your fingers to glide over your skin. Make circular motions to soothe your muscles and relieve your cramps. You can massage your lower abdomen as often as necessary. Sip on warm liquids like tea or cocoa to soothe your pain. Warm liquids will relax your body, which may help relieve your pain. Make your favorite tea or a mug of cocoa or simply drink hot water. Sip your beverage slowly to help you relax. You might also enjoy hot soups, such as chicken noodle soup. The hot broth can be soothing. Coping with Your Emotions Stay away from people who won’t understand. While many people will be there to support you, some people may judge your decision or say hurtful things. These people won’t help your recovery, so don’t let them around you. Instead, spend time with people who are there to help you. If you think someone might have a bad reaction, don’t tell them about your abortion. You don’t need their opinion about your healthcare needs. Give yourself permission to grieve if you're upset. While having an abortion may have been your best or only option, you might still feel a sense of sadness or loss. It’s normal to feel this way, and it doesn’t mean you made the wrong decision. Let yourself feel whatever comes naturally, and take your time during your recovery. Be aware: Some circumstances will put you at greater risk of having a difficult emotional recovery after an abortion. These include a history of previous emotional problems (such as depression or anxiety disorders), severe medical complications, coercion or lack of support from family members or your partner, or having to terminate a wanted pregnancy. It might be especially painful for you if you had to have an abortion because your pregnancy wasn’t viable. It’s normal to feel a lot of pain right now. Take as long as you need to feel better. Talk to someone you trust about the feelings you’re having. Reach out to your partner, a friend, or a family member you can trust. Tell them how you feel and ask them to be there to support you during your recovery. This can help you process your feelings faster. Don’t confide in someone who might judge you. Right now you need love and support.Tip: It’s normal to experience a range of emotions after an abortion. You might feel elated or relieved, but you could also feel sad or guilty. It’s okay to feel what comes naturally to you. Do fun activities to help you feel better. It might feel wrong to enjoy yourself right now, but it’s okay to do things that make you feel good. Take time for yourself every day to do something you enjoy. Here are some ways you might start to feel better. Express yourself through art. Watch funny movies. Listen to uplifting music. Color in an adult coloring book. Spend time with your friends. Talk to your doctor if your emotional pain troubles you. It’s normal for your hormones to fluctuate a lot after you have an abortion. You might even develop the symptoms of postpartum depression. If you’re worried that you’re depressed, talk to your doctor about how you feel. They may offer you treatment options. You aren’t to blame for feeling depressed. This is a medical issue, so visit your doctor. Visit a therapist if you need help dealing with your grief. You might need extra support during your recovery, and that’s okay. Work with a therapist to help you process your emotions and continue your recovery. Ask your doctor for a referral or look up a therapist online. Your counseling sessions may be covered by your insurance, so check your benefits.
